questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.1 Introduction to Moral Theology (FC 1))
questions.question: Understanding the principles upon which the Church's moral teachings rest is more important than solving particular moral problems, since:

choices.A: Human persons are not in control of their destiny, but are fated for salvation or damnation by God's will.
choices.B: Communicating moral truth effectively requires that we be able to explain why a given choice is good or bad.
choices.C: Morality is highly subjective, such that different people seldom agree on what is a good or fulfilling way to live

questions.explanation:
Communicating moral truth effectively requires that we be able to explain why a given choice is good or bad.
See FC, p. 4.

questions.section: 1.A. Freedom and Conscience (1.1 Introduction to Moral Theology (FC 1))
questions.question: Moral theology is the branch of theology concerned principally and properly with:

choices.A: The possibility of revelation itself and revealed truths concerning God.
choices.B: The offering of the Church's public worship, especially the sacraments.
choices.C: The relationship between human actions and goodness, in light of faith.

questions.explanation:
The relationship between human actions and
goodness, in light of faith.
See FC, pp. 1-2.
